section-block.rac_essential-question: How can we express ourselves through music and dance?

section-block.rac_book_title_byline: Written and illustrated by Ellie Sandall
section-block.rac_book_summary: The bunnies love to dance, play music, and sing! When Fox comes near, the bunnies hide. But Fox just wants to join them. And soon everyone is having fun!

section-block.rac_top-left_header: LET’s CREATE | WEEK 2: Sing and Dance

section-block.rac_body-text: Review that letters have names and special sounds. Practice the sounds in wagon, wolf, yo-yo, and yarn, using Alphabet Cards.
To help children get excited about reading the story, invite them to get up and dance! Play music, if available. Ask children to: shake, twist, twirl, hop, and spin.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read Everybunny Dance!, written and illustrated by Ellie Sandall.
Pablo loves narratives about animals. Especially bunnies that sing and dance!
There is a question I want you to think about as you read. We will talk about it after we read. Ready?
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What do the bunnies do to have fun?

section.rac_body-text: Read the book aloud and then read the Day 1 prompts.
Use Equity Sticks to choose children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Look at the title. Are all the letters in EVERYBUNNY uppercase letters or lowercase letters? How many letter Ys can you see?
What are the bunnies doing? How can you tell they are having fun?
Oh, look! It’s time for the bunnies to make music! What instruments do they play?
Uh-oh! I see a fox. Listen as I say the sounds in the word fox: /f/ /o/ /ks/. Now say the sounds and the word with me, /f/ /o/ /ks/, fox.
What do the bunnies do when they see the fox? Why is it a good idea for the bunnies to hide from the fox?
At the end of the story, Fox and the bunnies dance and play together. When do we sing, dance, and play together at school? (MB)
Let’s turn and talk about the guiding question.
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What do the bunnies do to have fun?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk.
Possible responses:
Write and read aloud a short sentence about how the bunnies sing and dance.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What is the first thing the bunnies do to have fun?
The bunnies d________ (dance) to have fun.
The bunnies dance to have fun.
What musical instruments do the bunnies play?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Research shows that children learn the letters of the alphabet best when instruction focuses on five things: letter name, letter sound, phonological awareness, letter in printed text, and letter formation.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: LET’s CREATE | WEEK 2: Sing and Dance

section-block.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule_day_2: Share the Mind Builder: Make Connections
section-block.rac_teacher-talk_blue: When you make a connection, you take something you learned in one place and use it in another place. Is there something that you learned to do at home, but then also did at school? What was that? Is there something that you saw a character do in a book and then decided to try to do yourself? What was that?

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to think about our making connections Mind Builder as we revisit the book Everybunny Dance! by Ellie Sandall.
This narrative is about bunnies who like to dance, play music, and sing. Pablo makes a connection with the characters and tries to dance, play music, and sing like they did.

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to the Mind Builder
section.rac_body-text: Use Equity Sticks during reading to choose children to answer questions.
Read the book aloud and then read the Day 2 prompts.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Look at the pictures. Which words tell about how the bunnies move? You can make a connection and use ideas from this story when you dance. Which of these moves will you use when you hear music? (MB)
Now you see how the bunnies play instruments. If someone gave you a flute, show me how you would play it. How would you play a violin? (MB)
Fox asks the bunnies to watch him. What does Fox do? How did Fox learn to do those things?
What do you say to friends when you think they have done a good job? What could the bunnies say to Fox? (MB)
What surprises the lonely fox after he performs?
Let’s make plans to play Follow the Leader. It’s good to think ahead and figure out the steps to take to reach our goal of playing the game. What should we do?
section.rac_body-text: Children may contribute ideas similar to these:
1. First we will choose someone to be the leader.
2. Then we will decide whether to play standing up or sitting down.
3. Then we will watch the leader and follow her.
After you play, have a conversation about making plans and taking steps to reach a goal. (MB)
Transcribe children’s speech as about how much fun Fox had when he watched the bunnies.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Setting a goal and taking small steps to achieve it is a key Executive Function skill. When something new seems too big or overwhelming to learn, it can be broken down into smaller, more achievable steps that help us to reach goals and acquire new skills. (Cunningham, et al., 2000)

section-block.rac_top-left_header: LET’s CREATE | WEEK 2: Sing and Dance

section-block.rac_body-text: Read and act out the verse on page 20. Then ask: Which word rhymes with sound? (found) Then invite children to name words that rhyme with stay and still.
Share the following chant and invite children to join in and move: “Let’s do the bunny hop. Hop, hop, hop. Let’s do the bunny hop. ’Til it’s time to stop.”
Review vocabulary that will be used today.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to reread the book Everybunny Dance!, written and illustrated by Ellie Sandall.
Pablo loves this narrative because the author used her imagination to make up the story and draw the pictures.
This is the guiding question I want you to think about as we read the book:
What are some ways the bunnies move?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 3 prompts. Use Equity Sticks to choose two or three children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Listen for the rhyming words. What does ready rhyme with? What does chance rhyme with?
Let’s see how the bunnies move. What sound do you hear at the beginning of wiggle and whirl? Which letter makes that sound?
The words twist and twirl begin with the same sound. They sound a little bit alike, but they are different words. They have a connection. Show me how you twist. Now twirl!
The bunnies are frightened when they first see Fox. They say, “Everybunny run!”
Listen as I say the sounds in the word run: /r/ /u/ /n/. Now say the sounds and the word with me, /r/ /u/ /n/, run.
Fox did a waltz. A waltz is a dance. What sound does the w make that begins the word waltz?
Look! The bunnies and Fox gather round. They are having fun together. What are they doing?
Let’s turn and talk about the guiding question:
What are some ways the bunnies move?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk. Possible responses:
Share a pen with children as you work together to describe different ways the bunnies move.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What do the bunnies do when they dance?
How could the bunnies move in another way?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Large locomotor movements strengthen children’s muscle tone and prepare them for more distinct movements such as writing and using scissors. Dancing, jumping, and clapping to music is a great way to develop gross motor skills and help children feel confident as they move in the world!

section-block.rac_top-left_header: LET’S CREATE | WEEK 2: Sing and Dance

section-block.rac_teacher-talk_blue: We read about bunnies and a fox who are in the woods. Today we are going to visit a farm. What animals do you think we will see?
section-block.rac_body-text: Let’s imagine you met two goats who love to rhyme. The first goat says, “Goat.” The second goat says, “Coat.” Each time children say what the second goat says. (boat, float)

section.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule: Share the Big Chart of Big Ideas
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read Old MacDonald’s Farm. It is a song shown on a poster.
Pablo loves to sing songs. This song is about animals on a farm!

Everybunny Dance! is a story about animals who like to dance, play music, and sing. “Old MacDonald’s Farm” is a song we will sing about animals on a farm. Let’s see if we can find some connections between the song and the story.
section.rac_body-text: Use Equity Sticks during reading to choose children to answer questions.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: As we read the Big Chart, let’s think about how it connects to this week’s concept question:
How can we express ourselves through music and dance?

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to Singing and Dancing
section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the teacher text on the Big Chart, and sing the song with children. Use these prompts to discuss the child-facing poster together.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What do you see on this farm? Which animal is your favorite farm animal? (MB)
Let’s name each of these animals. Is there one chicken or more than one? Is there one chick or more than one?
How many goats can you see? Who can point to the letter g that begins goats? How many ducks do you see? Who can point to the letter d that begins ducks?
What words did the horse say? Now let’s add animals from the Big Book to this song. What might the bunnies say?

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to sing “Old MacDonald’s Farm” again. This time, add movements to go with each animal’s sounds.
Provide a writing prompt about farm animals. Encourage children to write the letters that begin each word or any letters they know.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Multilingual learners benefit when they share and work with peers. In small groups, invite them to share animal names and sounds in their home language, and allow their English speaking peers to share the English names and sounds for each animal.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: LET’s CREATE | WEEK 2: Sing and Dance

section-block.rac_body-text: Invite children to imagine they are the characters, the bunnies and Fox, in Everybunny Dance! Play music and, if available, distribute simple percussion instruments such as wood blocks, triangles, or tambourines. Encourage children to make up their own music and moves and then dance!

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we’ll retell and reenact the book Everybunny Dance!, written and illustrated by Ellie Sandall.
This narrative is fiction because the author made up the characters and the story. Pablo loves to read made-up stories!
This week we read all about the bunnies and Fox. As we read the book one more time, let’s think about this guiding question:
What are some ways we dance, play music, and sing?

section.rac_body-text: Reread and retell the story in the Big Book together. Use Equity Sticks to pick children to actively participate in the discussion.
Point to the shadow of the fox in the upper righthand corner.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today, we need one person to be Fox as we read. The rest of us will imagine we are the bunnies.
section.rac_body-text: Invite a child to play the part of Fox, hiding until it is time for them to come out.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Okay, bunnies! Let’s dance. Clap your paws. Twist. Twirl. Now shake your tail.
Now the bunnies play instruments. Pretend to bang a drum. Pretend to blow a horn.
Here comes Fox! Bunnies, you hide and watch quietly while the fox dances and plays.
Now, bunnies, clap and cheer for Fox!
We’ve had such fun singing and dancing together. When I tell you to, let’s all cheer and show how happy we are. Ready? One, two, three, “Hooray!”

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to turn and talk about the guiding question:
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What are some ways we dance, play music, and sing?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk.
Possible responses:
Invite children to draw or write details about the way they sang or danced this week. Encourage children to write the letters they know in the words they write.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: How can we make music with our hands?
What are some other ways we can make music?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Preschool children are always on the move! Incorporating movement and play into their day not only makes learning fun, but also helps to reinforce connections in children’s brains that help them to learn and retain new skills.
